Award.AbstractNarration:
This research examines the ways in which authoritarian systems negatively characterize protestors in order to protect their own legitimacy and justify the use of harsh repression. While research has examined how social movements articulate their grievances, this study will make a contribution by analyzing how repressive systems frame their messages and the implications those frames have for citizens. This project focuses on the historical case of popular resistance to a 1953 currency reform in Czechoslovakia, one of the first uprisings against Communism in the Eastern Bloc.

This project will draw upon extensive examination of archival legal documents and in-depth interviews with protest participants, to analyze how characterizations of protesters served to legitimate state interests and influence repression. The findings will have relevance for understanding how other authoritarian systems have historically repressed citizens and quashed public protest. The research will result in the creation of large data sets that will be available to educators, scholars, and the public via the Internet. This study has important educational impacts, as its findings will contribute to the development of college level courses in sociology and history, and it will provide hands-on training in research and collaborative opportunities with the principal investigator for students at North Carolina State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Authoritarian governments often suppress popular protest in order to maintain their control over the public, but the methods regimes use to legitimate this repression are not well understood. This project examines the case of popular resistance to a 1953 currency reform in Czechoslovakia to understand how Communist Party officials responded to the protest. The currency reform had devastating consequences for the population, including the extreme devaluation of personal savings and reduced pricing subsidies for food. Protests broke out in several cities and the authoritarian government repressed the uprising with excessive police and military force. This study analyzed how officials characterized protestors in order to protect the state’s legitimacy and justify their use of harsh repression. Following the protest event, the government engaged in a campaign to vilify protestors, which set the stage for severe forms of punishment. Those found guilty in the Communist-controlled courts were sentenced to years in prison and hard labor in work camps and uranium mines.

Our interest in this case began with an apparent paradox. The majority of protestors hailed from the working class – the very people who had supposedly gained control of the country when the Communist Party took power in 1948. How then did Communist officials explain and justify the harsh repression that they brought against these workers? By answering these questions, we learned more about how authoritarian regimes legitimate their rule, especially when faced with popular protest. Drawing on over 6,000 pages of government archival documents, we constructed a dataset of how state officials characterized, or framed, the protesters and protests. This statistical profile of elite framing allowed us to analyze the core themes used by government officials to vilify protest participants. Additionally, in-depth interviews with protesters provided insights how protest participants and other witnesses perceived the government’s framing of the event. By quantifying archival data from government sources and combining it with interview data with protesters, this study offers a more advanced and comprehensive research design for studying protest and repression.

Results reveal several noteworthy findings that advance our understanding of authoritarian responses to protest activity. First, official framing of both the event and participants protected state interests by labeling protesters as “enemies of the state” and explained the spontaneous protest as an organized counter-revolution. These frames first emerged at the highest levels of the Communist party, before filtering down to judicial officials at the local level. Importantly, we found that court officials then relied on these frames when sentencing individual participants, which highlights how elite framing efforts can have serious repercussions for protester repression. Second, our research found that state framing played a crucial role in maintaining elite unity. We know that mass uprisings threaten regime legitimacy, and they can contribute to elite divisions by calling into question the competency and popularity of authoritarian rulers. In the case of the 1953 currency reform, the protest forced Communist party officials to confront institutional failures that had allowed the demonstration to emerge in the first place. Our research highlights how officials explained the event and organizational breakdown to other elites in order to ensure regime longevity. 

The study expands our current theoretical literature and offers a new research agenda for future studies on the ways in which authoritarian governments vilify and repress citizens. While the study utilizes a historical case of government repression, the research findings will have broader implications for contemporary authoritarian regimes.  The research has practical application for policy in terms of elite legitimation of protest repression in contemporary society, and can help academics, government officials, and NGOs better anticipate and plan for repressive episodes. Impacts also include the training of graduate students.
